description.short: Measures vulnerability created when organizations unconsciously seek 'silver bullet' security solutions and over-rely on specific vendors, tools, or personnel for protection, creating dangerous single points of failure
description.context: Organizations experiencing dependency group assumptions unconsciously seek omnipotent security solutions and transfer responsibility to external protective figures. This creates dangerous single points of failure where attackers can exploit the organization's blind trust in their chosen protective figures. When security responsibility is psychologically transferred to external entities, internal vigilance and critical thinking deteriorate, making organizations vulnerable to vendor impersonation attacks, fraudulent security solutions, and supply chain compromises.
description.impact: Organizations with high dependency scores experience vendor impersonation attacks exploiting trusted relationships, supply chain compromises through idealized security partners, and critical failures when single-point dependencies fail. Historical incidents include the SolarWinds attack leveraging extreme vendor trust and Equifax breach demonstrating over-reliance on external security assurances while failing internal vigilance.
description.psychological_basis: Bion's Group Dynamics Theory (1961) identifies dependency (baD) as one of three unconscious basic assumptions groups adopt when work group functioning is threatened by anxiety. Groups regress to infantile psychological states where they collectively abandon adult responsibility, instead seeking an idealized parent figure who will handle all threats. This creates profound vulnerability because the group's security posture becomes entirely dependent on the perceived strength of the protective figure while losing capacity for independent threat assessment.

scoring.formula: Final_Score = (w1 √ó Quick_Assessment + w2 √ó Conversation_Depth + w3 √ó Red_Flags) √ó Interdependency_Multiplier

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient
green.description: Distributed security approach with budget spread across multiple vendors, multiple staff authorized to make routine security decisions, quarterly vendor performance reviews, internal problem-solving capacity, tested backup solutions for critical security tools.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Moderate dependency indicators including single vendor receiving 30-50% of security budget, most security decisions require senior approval but multiple people can approve, annual vendor reviews conducted but limited changes result.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: High dependency vulnerability with single vendor receiving >50% of security budget, only 1-2 people authorized to make security decisions, vendor reviews infrequent or superficial, immediate external consultation is standard response to any security issue.

DI.calculation: Ratio of external authority requests to internal security decisions
DI.query: SELECT (COUNT(action='external_consult') / COUNT(action='internal_resolve')) FROM security_decisions WHERE time_window='24h'

ARF.calculation: Frequency of vendor/authority references in security communications
ARF.query: SELECT (COUNT(contains_vendor_reference=true) / COUNT(*)) FROM security_communications WHERE timestamp > NOW() - INTERVAL '7 days'

VC.query: SELECT (MAX(vendor_spend) / SUM(security_spend)) FROM vendor_payments WHERE fiscal_year=current

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Vendor Concentration Risk
items.question: What percentage of your annual cybersecurity budget goes to your top security vendor? Include all services, licenses, and support contracts from that single vendor.

options.label: Less than 30% - Security budget distributed across multiple vendors with no single vendor dominating
30-50% - Significant vendor concentration but not complete dependency
Over 50% - Single vendor receives majority of security budget creating critical dependency

items.evidence_required: Last 12 months security vendor payments breakdown, vendor contract terms

items.title: Security Decision Authority Distribution
items.question: When your primary security tool alerts or fails, who makes the decision about how to respond? How often do security decisions require approval from senior leadership before action can be taken?

options.label: Multiple staff authorized to make routine security decisions without senior approval required
Most security decisions require senior approval but multiple people can approve
Only 1-2 people authorized to make security decisions, creating single points of failure

items.evidence_required: Security decision authorization matrix, recent decision logs showing approvers

items.title: Vendor Performance Review Frequency
items.question: How frequently does your organization formally review and challenge the effectiveness of your main security vendors? Tell us about your most recent vendor performance audit and what changes resulted from it.

options.label: Quarterly vendor performance reviews with documented improvements and measurable changes
Annual vendor reviews conducted but limited changes result from findings
Vendor reviews infrequent or superficial with no resulting changes to vendor relationships

items.evidence_required: Vendor performance review reports, documented improvements from reviews
items.soc_mapping: Vendor review frequency from audit logs

items.title: Internal vs External Incident Response
items.question: When a security incident occurs, what's your first response: engage internal team problem-solving or immediately contact external vendors/consultants? Give us a specific example from a recent incident.

options.label: Internal team attempts problem-solving before external consultation (30-minute internal assessment minimum)
Mixed approach with some internal problem-solving but frequent immediate external consultation
Immediate external vendor/consultant contact is standard response to any security issue

items.evidence_required: Incident response logs showing first response patterns, escalation timelines
items.soc_mapping: DI metric (internal vs external resolution ratio)

items.title: Security Solution Evaluation Process
items.question: Describe your process for evaluating new security tools before purchase. How many solutions do you typically compare, and what evidence do you require beyond vendor demonstrations?

options.label: Systematic evaluation comparing 3+ solutions with proof-of-concept testing and reference checks
Limited evaluation process comparing 2-3 solutions with basic vendor demonstrations
Minimal evaluation, typically accept vendor recommendations without comparison or testing

items.evidence_required: Recent security tool selection documentation, POC testing reports, vendor comparison matrices
items.soc_mapping: Vendor evaluation thoroughness from procurement logs

items.title: Key Personnel Dependency
items.question: If your CISO or primary security contact was unavailable for two weeks, how would security decisions be made? Who has the knowledge and authority to maintain security operations?

options.label: Documented succession plan with cross-trained personnel who can maintain security operations
Some cross-training exists but gaps in key knowledge areas would create challenges
Single point of failure in security knowledge/authority with no viable backup

items.evidence_required: Security role succession documentation, cross-training records, backup authorization matrix
items.soc_mapping: Decision authority concentration from authorization logs

items.title: Backup Security Solutions
items.question: For your most critical security tool, what backup or alternative solution would you use if it failed completely? Tell us about the last time you tested these backup procedures.

options.label: Tested backup solutions for critical security tools with quarterly testing and documented procedures
Backup solutions identified but rarely or never tested in practice
No viable backup for critical security tools or completely untested alternatives

items.evidence_required: Backup procedure documentation, testing records, alternative vendor contact information
items.soc_mapping: Backup system availability from configuration management database

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: What percentage of your annual cybersecurity budget goes to your top security vendor, and how did this concentration develop over time?

scoring_guidance.green: Specific budget breakdown showing <30% concentration with documented vendor diversification strategy
scoring_guidance.yellow: 30-50% concentration with awareness of risk but limited diversification plans
scoring_guidance.red: >50% concentration with justifications like 'they're the best' or 'integration benefits' without risk mitigation

followups.text: What would happen to your security operations if this vendor relationship ended tomorrow?
When was the last time you seriously evaluated alternative vendors for these services?

items.text: How frequently does your organization formally review and challenge the effectiveness of your main security vendors?

scoring_guidance.green: Quarterly reviews with documented performance metrics and specific improvements implemented
scoring_guidance.yellow: Annual reviews conducted but minimal changes result from findings
scoring_guidance.red: Vendor relationships continue without formal review or 'we trust them' responses

followups.text: Show me the most recent vendor performance review and what specific actions resulted from it.
Have you ever changed or terminated a vendor relationship based on performance review findings?

items.text: When a security incident occurs, describe the decision-making process. Who has authority to take action, and when do you engage external help?

scoring_guidance.green: Internal-first approach with 30+ minute internal assessment before external escalation, multiple authorized responders
scoring_guidance.yellow: Mixed approach with some internal capability but frequent immediate external consultation
scoring_guidance.red: Immediate external vendor contact is standard first response, minimal internal problem-solving

followups.text: Walk me through a recent security incident and the specific decision points.
If your primary security vendor was unreachable during an incident, what would your team do?

items.text: If your CISO or primary security decision-maker was unavailable for two weeks, how would security operations continue?

scoring_guidance.green: Documented succession plan with cross-trained personnel, recent example of successful coverage
scoring_guidance.yellow: Informal backup arrangements but acknowledged gaps in critical knowledge
scoring_guidance.red: Single point of failure with no viable backup or 'we'd have to wait for them' responses

followups.text: Show me your security role succession documentation and cross-training records.
When was the last time backup personnel actually made security decisions independently?

items.text: Describe your process for evaluating new security tools before purchase. How do you ensure you're not just accepting vendor promises?

scoring_guidance.green: Systematic evaluation with 3+ vendor comparisons, POC testing, reference checks, documented criteria
scoring_guidance.yellow: Basic evaluation comparing 2-3 vendors with demos but limited hands-on testing
scoring_guidance.red: Minimal evaluation accepting vendor recommendations or single-vendor assessments without comparison

followups.text: Show me the evaluation documentation from your most recent security tool purchase.
Have you ever rejected a vendor recommendation in favor of a different solution after evaluation?

items.text: For your most critical security tools, what backup or alternative solutions exist if they fail?

scoring_guidance.green: Tested backup solutions with quarterly testing and documented failover procedures
scoring_guidance.yellow: Identified backup options but minimal or no testing of actual failover
scoring_guidance.red: No backup solutions or 'we'd have to figure it out' responses

followups.text: When was the last time you tested your backup security procedures?
What happened during that test and what did you learn?

solutions.title: Vendor Portfolio Diversification
solutions.description: Implement policy requiring no single vendor to exceed 40% of security budget
solutions.implementation: Create formal vendor diversification plan with timeline for redistribution of services across multiple providers. Establish competitive bidding requirements for contracts over specified thresholds. Document vendor concentration risk assessments quarterly.
solutions.technical_controls: Procurement system alerts for vendor concentration thresholds, automated vendor spend tracking, competitive bidding workflow enforcement

solutions.title: Distributed Decision Authority Matrix
solutions.description: Document authorization levels for different security decisions ensuring multiple personnel can approve routine responses
solutions.implementation: Create clear escalation procedures that don't create single points of failure. Implement deputy/backup authorization for all critical security roles. Develop decision trees for when external help is appropriate.
solutions.technical_controls: Authorization workflow system, decision logging with approver tracking, automated escalation routing

solutions.title: Quarterly Vendor Performance Reviews
solutions.description: Establish standardized vendor assessment criteria including security effectiveness metrics and cost-benefit analysis
solutions.implementation: Require vendors to demonstrate measurable improvements in security posture. Document specific actions taken based on review findings. Create vendor scorecard system with improvement tracking.
solutions.technical_controls: Vendor performance management system, automated metrics collection, review schedule tracking

solutions.title: Internal Security Response Protocols
solutions.description: Develop 'internal first' incident response procedures requiring 30-minute internal assessment before external consultation
solutions.implementation: Train staff in basic incident response to reduce external dependence. Create decision trees for when external help is appropriate. Document internal resolution capabilities and limits.
solutions.technical_controls: Incident response playbook automation, internal capability tracking, escalation timer system

solutions.title: Security Solution Evaluation Framework
solutions.description: Implement standardized evaluation requiring comparison of minimum 3 vendors with proof-of-concept testing
solutions.implementation: Create evaluation criteria focused on objective security improvements rather than vendor promises. Require documented justification for single-vendor selections. Include reference checks and POC testing in all evaluations.
solutions.technical_controls: Evaluation workflow system, POC testing environment, vendor comparison scoring matrix

solutions.title: Backup Security Operations Plan
solutions.description: Document alternative procedures for each critical security function if primary tools fail
solutions.implementation: Test backup solutions quarterly with documented results. Maintain current contact lists for alternative vendors. Ensure staff know backup procedures through regular drills.
solutions.technical_controls: Backup procedure documentation system, testing schedule automation, alternative vendor contact database

risk_scenarios.title: Vendor Impersonation Attack
risk_scenarios.description: Attacker impersonates trusted security vendor via email or phone, requesting urgent access to address critical vulnerabilities
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Social engineering via vendor impersonation leveraging organizational trust in primary security vendor
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Dependency assumption makes verification feel unnecessary when trusted vendor makes requests
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Multiple organizations compromised through fake vendor support calls exploiting vendor trust relationships

risk_scenarios.title: False Authority Exploitation
risk_scenarios.description: During security incidents, attackers position themselves as emergency consultants or experts offering immediate help
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Crisis exploitation where attackers pose as security experts during active incidents
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Organizational anxiety and dependency activate immediate trust in apparent expert helpers
risk_scenarios.historical_example: APT campaigns maintaining persistence by posing as incident responders offering assistance

risk_scenarios.title: Silver Bullet Solution Scam
risk_scenarios.description: Fraudulent vendors target organizations seeking comprehensive security solutions, selling ineffective tools by exploiting desire for complete protection
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Fraudulent security product marketing targeting organizations exhibiting dependency patterns
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Magical thinking about omnipotent security solutions bypasses normal due diligence
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Numerous snake oil security products sold to desperate organizations seeking quick fixes

risk_scenarios.title: Supply Chain Compromise
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers infiltrate the trusted vendor that dependency-oriented organizations rely on heavily
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Compromise of trusted security vendor to gain access to dependent customer organizations
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Organizational splitting prevents questioning or monitoring of idealized protective vendors
risk_scenarios.historical_example: SolarWinds 2020 - Organizations' trust in security software vendor enabled supply chain attack affecting 18,000+ customers
